**Introduction to Neuromorphic Computing and its Applications in Brain-Machine Interfaces**

Neuromorphic computing is a field that simulates the complex, multi-threaded processing power of the human brain. The underlying principles of neuromorphic computing are inspired by biological neural networks and can be summarized as follows:

**Fundamentals of Neuromorphic Computing:
• Biologically-Inspired Architecture: Inspired by biological neural networks in terms of structure and operation
• Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs): Functioning on discrete neural events, allowing for efficient, event-driven computation
• Event-Driven Computation: Computes only in response to events, unlike traditional computing

**Applications of Neuromorphic Computing in Brain-Machine Interfaces (BMIs)**

• Enhancement of Signal Processing:
	+ Multi-neuronal signal acquisition through low-power, high-density recording arrays
	+ Improves language interface expressivity and motor control fluency
• Packaging Optimizations:
	+ With wireless modules, flexible materials
	+ Intelligent power allocation for portable assistive applications
	+ Real-time environmental feedback and untethered operation
• Neuroplasticity Co-processors:
	+ Combining cortical activity decoding and spike-based learning rules
	+ Supporting neurorehabilitation by advancing BMI technologies

**Key Concepts:**

• Biologically-inspired architecture
• Spiking neural networks (SNNs)
• Event-driven computation
• Multi-threaded processing power
• Brain-machine interfaces (BMIs)
• Neurorehabilitation**
• Neuromorphic computing fundamentals
